welcome: Welcome to the Denial and Appeal Wizard.
My name is Mattie, the official ChatBot of “Matters of the Heart” by Patient Advocate Foundation.
Can you tell me your name?

init.1: It’s nice to chat with you today <name>
init.2: I’m new to this job and am still in training, but I’ve worked with many experienced case managers recently and am confident that I can provide some specific steps for the care you need and connect you with resources to use.
init.Prompt: I understand you have had a denial from your insurance company. Have you received a denial letter, an explanation of benefits (EOB), or spoken to your provider or insurance verbally about the denial?

next.Prompt: Ok, that helps. Which of these best matches the situation you have?
Choices: No payment towards a service I already received
No coverage for medication I need
Denial of request for care my doctor wants me to have

next.Prompt: Can you tell me which of these best matches the reason provided for the denial?
Choices: The doctor is not in network with my health plan

next.1: Thanks so much for sharing <name>. I hate to hear that you are facing such a challenge with your healthcare. I understand that your doctor performed a service or treatment for you that your health plan is not paying for because they feel it was not medically necessary.
next.2: As frustrating as it might seem, your situation is not uncommon. There are many reasons this could happen. If the service you had used a new technique, your health plan may deny it. Or, if there are other procedures that are similar and cheaper, the health plan may decide you could have had the less costly service.
next.3: Review your EOB or denial letter carefully as it outlines your next steps for appealing the decision. You may be entitled to a peer to peer review of your case. This review is a meeting, most often a phone conversation, between a doctor at your insurance company and your treating doctor.
next.4: Getting the two doctors on the phone is a good thing because your doctor can better explain the reasoning for ordering the services as well as give extra details about your case. Sometimes the denial can be overturned at this stage.
next.5: If a peer to peer review is not available, or if it is denied, you have the option of moving forward with the formal appeals process.
next.Prompt: Do you want to hear more about the appeals process?

next.1: The first step is to get all your paperwork together. You should request a letter of support from the doctor explaining the medical reasons the requested service should be approved as well as any medical records, evidence of any previously tried and failed treatments, results of any relevant tests or procedures, or current research articles.
next.2: As you write your appeal letter, make sure you are being complete and using facts to make your argument. Your main point needs to address the denial reason given by the health plan, and you should provide evidence that shows your insurance company they should cover the treatment or service.
next.3: Try not to get too emotional or frustrated in the letter because that could take away from the points you are making.
next.4: Send the letter by certified mail with a request for return receipt. Keep records of any tracking numbers and mark your calendar for when you should hear back with a decision.
next.5: Your health plan should send a notice after your appeal packet has been received within 7-10 days. If you don’t get one, give your insurance company a call to check on it.
next.6: Finally, remain organized. If you haven’t already, keep copies of everything you submitted and notes from all your calls with dates, times, and who you spoke with in case you need it later.
next.Prompt: Did that help?

next.1: Thanks for sharing <name>. I’m sorry to hear that you are facing this challenge with your healthcare. I understand that your doctor has performed a service or treatment for you that your health plan is not paying for because the doctor is out of network.
next.2: This is typical if your insurance is a health maintenance organization (HMO) or an exclusive provider organization (EPO). Going out of an HMO or EPO network means you’re seeing a provider who hasn’t agreed to your insurance company’s terms of payment.
next.3: If you do not have any out-of-network benefits, your health plan will most likely deny your doctor’s charges, making payment your responsibility, or require you to pay a bigger share of the cost if you have the service.
next.4: If you received the out-of-network services due to an emergency, you should call your health plan and ask that the charges be re-processed. At this time, you can provide details about the situation and why you were forced to go out-of-network.
next.5: If the charges remain unpaid after reprocessing, or if the services were not due to an emergency, you should have the right to move forward with the appeals process.

next.1: Thanks for the helpful information! Most health plans have a list of covered medications called a formulary, that are chosen by a committee made up of doctors and pharmacists. This committee reviews medications based on things like how effective the medications are and their safety. Health plans have the option to change the formulary at any time, even in the middle of a plan year.
next.2: Sometimes the medication your doctor has prescribed for you is not on your formulary, but that does not mean the medication is not safe or effective.
next.3: You can always ask your doctor about switching medications. There may be a generic version of the drug that is on your formulary, or your doctor may want to try a different medication altogether.
next.4: You also may choose to pay outright for the medication. You would be paying full retail price for the medication, but ask about help available through a special program, a discount card, or medication assistance programs to help with the cost if you choose to go this route.
next.5: Lastly, if the above are not options, you and your doctor can ask the health plan to make a special allowance for you to have the medication your doctor wants you to have, called a formulary exception.
next.Prompt: Would you like more information on filing for a formulary exception?

next.1: Before you begin, call your health plan to see if there are any special forms that must be sent with the request. If your doctor feels your life or health is at risk by waiting for a standard request (typically 30 days), the plan must give your case an urgent review (typically 72 hours).
next.2: When you submit the formulary exception request to your health plan, they will need to know why other medication on the plan’s formulary will not work for you, a list of any alternative medications you have tried for this issue and why those did not work for you including any negative side effects. Also, if you are already taking the requested medication, make sure you let them know how well it is working for you.
next.3: Your health plan is likely to grant your request for exception if their lack of coverage would mean you are forced to use a medication that won’t work well for you, or will cause you to have a harmful medical event or issue.
next.4: If your request for an exception is turned down by the health plan, you have the right to appeal the health plan’s decision. Health plans are required by law to have a formal appeals process.

next.1: Thanks for the helpful information! Most health plans have a list of covered medications called a formulary, that are chosen by a committee made up of doctors and pharmacists. This committee reviews medications based on things like how effective the medications are and their safety. Health plans have the option to change the formulary at any time, even in the middle of a plan year.
next.2: Often, restrictions are also placed on certain drugs. The particular medication you are taking appears to have a limit restriction. It’s common for medications with serious side effects, that are harmful when combined with other medications, or are often misused or abused to have restrictions.
next.3: When a covered medication has a quantity limit, the plan will cover only a set amount within a set period of time, for example 30 tablets in 30 days. If you attempt to fill the prescription before the 30 days is up, or if your doctor prescribes an amount that is higher than the limit, it may not be covered by the plan.
next.4: The same is true with a dose limit. This limitation is put into place to restrict medications to the specific number of doses based on FDA warnings and common prescribing practices. If your doctor writes you a prescription that exceeds the normal dose, your health plan will most likely not cover the medications.
next.5: But, you do have options if you are facing a dose or quantity limit. You can ask your doctor to help you file for a medical exception to your health plan to try and get coverage for the medication.
next.Prompt: Would you like to hear more about the medical exception process?

next.1: Your doctor can provide documentation to your health plan about why it’s important for you to have the dosage or quantity prescribed. If there is proof that the medication is ineffective for you with normal dosage, or if there are studies that show a higher amount is safe, your health plan can make an exception for you to cover the drug.
next.2: Also, you do have the option to go ahead and purchase the medication without your insurance paying. There may be assistance available through a special program or a discount card. Ask your doctor or pharmacist about any programs to help with the cost if you choose to go this route.

next.2: A lot of health plans are now requiring patients on maintenance medications (prescribed for chronic, long-term conditions that are taken on a regular basis) to switch to mail order. If this is the case for you, you will need to keep up with different pharmacy providers and verify that all or your medication and insurance information is accurate with both.
next.3: In addition to cost savings, some meds are not often stocked at your local pharmacy, or require additional preparation and handling to dispense. next.4: If your prescription has been sent out, the new place will contact you to arrange delivery and verify your insurance information. Be sure to watch out for any toll-free phone numbers and check your voice messages frequently in case the pharmacy has been trying to reach you.
next.5: However, since you will likely still use your normal pharmacy for your other medications, be sure to let each know about all of the medications you’re taking and update both about any changes, so your pharmacist can alert you to any possible drug interactions.
next.6: If your plan is requiring you switch to a mail-order pharmacy but there is a legitimate reason this will not work for you, be sure to contact your health plan and inquire about an exception process.
next.7: You may have a concern regarding receiving your maintenance medications on time. You can pay extra to have overnight shipping, or your plan may allow you to go into a retail pharmacy and get a short 3 day supply to hold you over until your medication arrives.

next.1: Thanks for the helpful information! Most health plans have a list of covered medications called a formulary, that are chosen by a committee made up of doctors and pharmacists. This committee reviews medications based on things like how effective the medications are and their safety. Health plans have the option to change the formulary at any time, even in the middle of a plan year.
next.2: Since your doctor has prescribed a brand name medication and your health plan will not cover it, give the office a call to update them. Doctors often are not familiar with the specifics of patient’s formularies. There is a chance that the generic version will work just as well for you and the doctor may feel comfortable with you taking it.
next.3: If your doctor feels you require the brand name, you have a couple of options. You may choose to pay outright for the medication. You would be paying full retail price for the medication, but ask the pharmacist or your doctor about help available through a discount card or medication assistance program if you choose to go this route.
next.4: Or, you and your doctor can ask the health plan to make a special allowance for you to have the medication your doctor wants you to have, called a formulary exception.
next.Prompt: <name> would you like more information on filing for a formulary exception?

next.1: Before you begin, call your health plan to see if there are any special forms that must be sent with the request. If your doctor feels your life or health is at risk by waiting for a standard request (typically 30 days), the plan must give your case an urgent review (typically 72 hours).
next.2: When you submit the formulary exception request to your health plan, they will need to know why other medication on the plan’s formulary will not work for you, a list of any alternative medications you have tried for this issue and why those did not work for you including any negative side effects. Also, if you are already taking the requested medication, make sure you let them know how well it is working for you.
next.3: Your health plan is likely to grant your request for exception if their lack of coverage would mean you are forced to use a medication that won’t work well for you, or will cause you to have a harmful medical event or issue.
next.4: If your request for an exception is turned down by the health plan, you have the right to appeal the health plan’s decision. Health plans are required by law to have a formal appeals process.

This approval is a process where your doctor and your health plan agree that the prescribed service or medication is one you need. In this case, your health plan decided that you don’t need the service your doctor wants you to have.
next.3: There could be several reasons for this. If the service uses a new technique, your health plan may deny it. Or, if there are other procedures that are similar and cheaper, the health plan may decide you can go with the less costly service.

next.1: The first step is to get all your paperwork together. You should request a letter of support from the doctor explaining the medical reasons the requested service should be approved as well as any medical records, evidence of any previously tried and failed treatments, results of any relevant tests or procedures, or current research articles.
next.2: As you write your appeal letter, make sure you are being complete and using facts to make your argument. Your main point needs to address the denial reason given by the health plan, and you should provide evidence that shows your insurance company they should cover the treatment or service.
next.3: Try not to get too emotional or frustrated in the letter because that could take away from the points you are making.
next.4: Send the letter by certified mail with a request for return receipt. Keep records of any tracking numbers and mark your calendar for when you should hear back with a decision. next.1: The first step is to get all your paperwork together. You should request a letter of support from the doctor explaining the medical reasons the medication should have been approved as well as any medical records, evidence of any previously tried and failed treatments, results of any relevant tests or procedures, or current research articles. Make sure to include the receipt from where you paid for the medication and ask for reimbursement.
next.2: As you write your appeal letter, make sure you are being complete and using facts to make your argument. Your main point needs to address the denial reason given by the health plan, and you should provide evidence that shows your insurance company they should cover the treatment or service.
